dataset.title: Eight Mile Lake Research Watershed, Carbon in Permafrost Experimental Heating and Drying Research (DryPEHR): Phenology of Dominant Plant Species II - Berry Production 2015

address.deliveryPoint: PO Box 5620; Ecosystem Science and Society Center (ECOSS) ; Northern Arizona University
Center for Ecosystem Science and Society; PO Box 5620
Woods Hole Research Center, 149 Woods Hole Road
Center for Ecosystem Science and Society, POBox 5620

abstract.para: This drying and warming experiment addresses the following questions: 1) Does ecosystem drying, warming and permafrost thaw cause a net release or uptake of C from the ecosystem to the atmosphere?, 2) Does the decomposition of old C that comprises the bulk of the soil C pool influence ecosystem C loss? 3) How do drying and warming affect plant communities and ecosystem properties? We are answering these questions using a combined warming and drying experiment (DryPEHR), which is situated with the Carbon in Permafrost Experimental Heating Research (CiPEHR) project and located in an upland tundra field site near Healy, Alaska in the foothills of the Alaska Range. Warming treatment here refers to growing season air temperature warming (~1C) using open top chambers (OTC) combined with soil 'warming' using snow fences during the snow covered months. Drying is achieved using an automated pumping system that lowers the water table in the dry plots. Soil warming began in 2008; OTCs and drying in 2011. In this dataset we specifically ask, how does warming and drying of soil and air impact the phenology of dominant plant species? Phenological data was collected to determine the timing of first bud break, onset and completion of senescence, and reproductive effort (flower and berry production).

section.title: Access to Data
section.para: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

section.title: Use of data
section.para: Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

section.title: Citing Bonanza Creek LTER Datasets
section.para: It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Dataset geographic description information is unavailable. {datafile/e_long is not empty}

section.title: Methods
section.para: FIELD: Phenology of the dominant plant species was monitored throughout the growing season. Plots were surveyed starting after snow-melt through mid-September to determine the day of year (DOY) on which bud burst, and senescence occurred. Once plants had flowered, flowers and berries were counted in the entire plot (0.36m2) for each species. Bud burst was monitored 4 May - 15 June, Flowering 3 June -10 July, Berries 17 July - 22 August, Senescence 17 August - 17 September. The species observed were: Betula nana (bud, flower, senescence), Carex bigelowii (bud,flower senescence), Rubus chamaemorus (bud, flower, berry, senescence), Vaccinium Uliginosum (bud, flower, berry, sensecence), Vaccinium vitis-idaea (flower, berry), Eriophorum vaginatum (flower,senescence) and Rhododendron subarcticum (flower). Onset of senescence in B. nana and V. uliginosum was defined as at least one leaf with no green (turning red) and complete senescence when no leaves were green; in C. Bigelowii. E. vaginatum, and R. chamaemorus onset of senescence was defined as at least one leaf with no green (leaves turning yellow) and complete senescence if all leaves were yellow. Flowers were either counted as individual flowers (R. Chamaemorus, V. uliginosum, V. vitis-idaea), infloresence clusters (B. nana, R. subarcticum) or number of flowering tillers (C. Bigelowii, E. vaginatum). Each treatment had two pseudo-replicated subplots. If a phenological event was observed in at least one of these two subplots, that DOY was used to determine first occurrence. For flowers and berries averages were calculated from the two subplots, hence it is possible to have observed 0.5 flowers or berries.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: EML -- Tussock tundra at treeline with permafrost thaw and thermokarst. This site is in the Eight Mile Lake Watershed, west of the town of Healy on Stampede Road, Interior Alaska. This area contains three sites on a permafrost thaw gradient and a nearby experimental snow fence manipulation.. Site alternate names:

section.title: Sampling Frequency
section.para: 31 May - 17 September 2013. Data was collected every 3-7 days. 4 May - 17 September 2015. Data was collected every 3-7 days.

dataTable.entityDescription: Phenology of the dominant plant species was monitored througought the growing season. For flowers and berries averages were calculated from the two subplots, hence it is possible to have observed 0.5 flowers or berries.

attribute.attributeDefinition: sample year

textDomain.definition: sample year

attribute.attributeDefinition: Samples are collected in 3 blocks, each block contains 2 fences (1-2; 3-4; 5-6). Within a block each fence is a split plot, winter warmed on one side, ambient on the other. Fences within blocks are replicates of each other

textDomain.definition: Samples are collected in 3 blocks, each block contains 2 fences (1-2; 3-4; 5-6). Within a block each fence is a split plot, winter warmed on one side, ambient on the other. Fences within blocks are replicates of each other

attribute.attributeDefinition: Each fence contains 8 plots, 1-4 on the ambient side of the fence, 5-8 on the winter warmed side of the fence. Summer warming treatments are nested within winter warming treatments, plots 1, 3, 5, 7 have open top chambers to produce a summer warming effect.

textDomain.definition: Each fence contains 8 plots, 1-4 on the ambient side of the fence, 5-8 on the winter warmed side of the fence. Summer warming treatments are nested within winter warming treatments, plots 1, 3, 5, 7 have open top chambers to produce a summer warming effect.

attribute.attributeDefinition: W = winter warmed side; C= control/ambient side

attribute.attributeDefinition: S = summer or air warming; C=control

textDomain.definition: S = summer or air warming; C=control

attribute.attributeDefinition: treatment label - Air warming refers to presence of an open top chamber, Soil warming refers to the winter warmed plots in which increased snow cover produces elevated soil temperatures, Air & Soil warming refers to open top chamber and increased snow depth treatments, Ambient refers to no air or soil warming treatment.

textDomain.definition: treatment label - Air warming refers to presence of an open top chamber, Soil warming refers to the winter warmed plots in which increased snow cover produces elevated soil temperatures, Air & Soil warming refers to open top chamber and increased snow depth treatments, Ambient refers to no air or soil warming treatment.
